title: Pentecost and the Early Church
shortSummary: Acts chapter 2 describes the outpouring of the Holy Spirit on the day of Pentecost, empowering the apostles to speak in various tongues and boldly proclaim the gospel. Peter’s sermon explains the fulfillment of prophecy through Jesus Christ’s death, resurrection, and exaltation, leading to the conversion and baptism of about three thousand souls. The chapter concludes with the establishment of the early Christian community devoted to teaching, fellowship, and prayer.
timeline: c. AD 30-33 - The Day of Pentecost and the Birth of the Church

keyCharacters.name: Peter
keyCharacters.description: One of Jesus’ twelve apostles, who delivers the first public sermon explaining the Pentecost event and calls for repentance and baptism.

keyCharacters.name: The Eleven Apostles
keyCharacters.description: The remaining apostles who, along with Peter, receive the Holy Spirit and witness the birth of the early church.

keyCharacters.name: David
keyCharacters.description: The Old Testament king and prophet whose messianic psalms Peter cites to prove Jesus’ resurrection and exaltation.

definitions.definition: A Jewish feast celebrated fifty days after Passover, commemorating the giving of the Law at Sinai; here it marks the day the Holy Spirit was poured out on believers.
The third Person of the Trinity, who empowers and guides believers; synonymous with the Holy Spirit.
Languages spoken miraculously by the apostles enabling them to proclaim God’s works to diverse peoples.
To turn away from sin with sincere remorse and a commitment to change, a prerequisite for receiving forgiveness.

outline.heading: The Coming of the Holy Spirit
outline.description: On the day of Pentecost, the Holy Spirit descends with the sound of a mighty wind and tongues of fire, filling the apostles and enabling them to speak in various languages, signifying the Spirit’s power and presence.

outline.heading: The Multitude’s Amazement and Confusion
outline.description: Devout Jews from many nations hear the apostles speaking in their native tongues, causing amazement and confusion, with some mocking the believers as drunk.

outline.heading: Peter’s Sermon: Fulfillment of Prophecy
outline.description: Peter explains that the events fulfill Joel’s prophecy and testifies to Jesus’ life, death, resurrection, and exaltation, declaring Him both Lord and Christ.

outline.heading: Call to Repentance and Baptism
outline.description: The crowd is convicted and asks what to do; Peter calls them to repent, be baptized, and receive the Holy Spirit, resulting in about three thousand conversions.

outline.heading: Life in the Early Church
outline.description: The new believers devote themselves to the apostles’ teaching, fellowship, breaking of bread, and prayer, sharing possessions and growing in unity and favor.

application: Seek the empowering presence of the Holy Spirit to boldly witness and serve in unity with other believers.
Respond to conviction with repentance and baptism as a public declaration of faith and receiving God’s forgiveness.
Commit to regular fellowship, prayer, and study of Scripture to grow in faith and community.
Practice generosity and care for fellow believers, reflecting the early church’s example of sharing and unity.

keyVerses.text: And they were all filled with the Holy Ghost, and began to speak with other tongues, as the Spirit gave them utterance.
keyVerses.significance: This verse marks the miraculous empowerment of the apostles by the Holy Spirit, enabling the global proclamation of the gospel.

keyVerses.text: And it shall come to pass, that whosoever shall call on the name of the Lord shall be saved.
keyVerses.significance: A foundational promise of salvation available to all who call on Jesus, emphasizing God’s grace and accessibility.

keyVerses.text: Then Peter said unto them, Repent, and be baptized every one of you in the name of Jesus Christ for the remission of sins, and ye shall receive the gift of the Holy Ghost.
keyVerses.significance: Peter’s clear call to repentance, baptism, and receiving the Holy Spirit outlines the essential steps of Christian conversion.

keyVerses.text: And they continued stedfastly in the apostles' doctrine and fellowship, and in breaking of bread, and in prayers.
keyVerses.significance: Describes the foundational practices of the early church that sustain spiritual growth and community life.
